;

;卡内隆格兰德水库是乌拉圭缺水首都蒙得维的亚的主要水源，但水位一直很低，太长了，草现在覆盖了以前是湖泊的大部分地方。

;

;“真是荒凉”，当地人马里奥·德尔·皮诺站在水库中央，周围都是杂草和开裂的泥土，说道。

;

;“这里很荒凉。” p>;

;“水曾经覆盖了你能看到的一切。”

;

;这个拥有 350 万人口的南美国家正遭受 74 年来最严重的干旱，迫使沮丧的居民依赖瓶装水。 ” “太可怕了。你不能喝它，”阿德里安·迪亚斯老师说，他每两周购买两到三瓶 6.5 升（1.7 加仑）的水。 “我的妻子患有高血压，所以她不可能喝这种含盐量的水。”

;

;对缺水的愤怒在首都街头引发了多起抗议活动。在国有水务公司 OSE，涂鸦上写着“没有干旱，只有抢劫。”

;

;OSE 外悬挂的横幅上写着“有水，但它在私人手中”。

;< OSE 工会领导人费德里科·克雷默曼 (Federico Kreimerman) 表示，农业企业对乌拉圭的水问题负有部分责任，他解释说，圣卢西亚河的水被抽到私人水库用于灌溉。

;

;“人类消费量很小，”克雷默曼说。 “农业企业企业家在河上筑坝并为自己使用。”

;

;本月早些时候，乌拉圭政府宣布;水紧急情况;，免除瓶装水税并下令建造新水库。

;

;政府还向乌拉圭环境部副部长赫拉尔多·阿马里拉 (Gerardo Amarilla) 表示，学校、疗养院和医院等弱势群体。

;

;音乐家弗兰克·兰帕里耶洛 (Frank Lampariello) 在索利马尔一家超市购买瓶装水后表示，“这个问题是真实存在的” ，在蒙得维的亚的郊区。 “这很复杂，尤其是对于下层阶级来说。”

;;周四（6 月 29 日），法国主要城市发生了第三晚骚乱，总统埃马纽埃尔·马克龙 (Emmanuel Macron) 奋力遏制骚乱。一名阿尔及利亚和摩洛哥裔青少年在交通堵塞期间被警察开枪打死，引发了日益严重的骚乱。内政部长杰拉尔德·达尔马宁 (Gerald Darmanin) 周五在推特上表示，法国各地一夜之间至少有 667 人被捕。 Ryan Chang 报道。;
;

;法国政府表示，将在周五研究恢复秩序的“所有选择”，此前全国骚乱一夜之间升级为自警察在一个青少年中心开枪打死以来最具破坏性的骚乱。交通停止。当局称，骚乱者在法国各地城镇与警察发生冲突，建筑物和车辆被烧毁，商店被抢劫，数百名警察受伤，数百人被捕。

;< p>;内政部长杰拉尔德·达马宁 (Gerald Darmanin) 在周四晚上将警察部署增加了四倍，达到 40,000 名警察，以平息第三晚的骚乱，他在 Twitter 上表示，警方逮捕了 667 人。

;

;全国范围内有 249 名警察当局称，有人在冲突中受伤。内政部表示，79 个警察哨所以及 119 座公共建筑遭到袭击，其中包括 34 座市政厅和 28 所学校。

;

;总统埃马纽埃尔·马克龙 (Emmanuel Macron) 正在途中，目前他尚未宣布宣布进入紧急状态。提前离开欧盟峰会后从布鲁塞尔飞往巴黎，以便参加两天内的第二次内阁危机会议。

;

;总理伊丽莎白·博恩表示，政府将研究恢复秩序的“所有选项”，并呼吁推文中的暴力行为“无法容忍且不可原谅”。

;

;“当务之急是确保民族团结，而实现这一目标的方法就是恢复秩序，”她后来在访问巴黎郊区时告诉记者。

;

;马赛、里昂、波城、图卢兹和里尔以及巴黎部分地区再次爆发暴力事件，其中包括南泰尔的工人阶级郊区，17 岁的阿尔及利亚人和摩洛哥裔 - 于周二被枪杀。

;

;他的死引发了长期以来对警察暴力和执法机构内部、权利团体以及法国主要城市周围低收入、种族混杂郊区的系统性种族主义的抱怨。

;

;社交媒体上的一夜之间的视频显示了全国各地的城市景观。东部城市里昂的一辆有轨电车被纵火，巴黎北部奥贝维利埃的一个车站内 12 辆公交车被烧毁。

;

;邻近的奥贝维利耶水上运动中心的正面，这里将进行 2024 年奥运会的训练，在火灾中;轻微损坏;，SOLIDEO -负责奥运会基础设施的公司 - 告诉路透社。

;

;在首都郊区的南泰尔，抗议者在早些时候举行和平守夜活动以悼念死者后，焚烧汽车，封锁街道并向警察投掷投掷物

;

;巴黎警方称，在巴黎市中心的 Chatelet Les Halles 购物中心，一家耐克鞋店被闯入，邻近的里沃利路 (Rue de Rivoli) 购物街的商店橱窗被砸碎，数人被捕。 .

;

;交通部长克莱门特·博纳 (Clement Beaune) 周五早些时候对 RMC 电台表示，他不排除关闭首都公共交通网络的可能性。

;

;一位消息人士告诉路透社，数家赌场超市遭到抢劫。

;

;在日内瓦，联合国人权办公室强调和平集会的重要性，并敦促法国当局确保警察使用武力的合法性、相称性和非歧视性。

;

;发言人拉维纳·沙姆达萨尼 (Ravina Shamdasani) 表示：“现在是国家认真解决执法中种族主义和种族歧视的深层次问题的时刻。”

;

;人权组织指控法国执法机构内部存在系统性种族主义，马克龙否认了这一指控。 2020 年，他的政府承诺对执法机构内的种族主义“零容忍”。

;

;检察官称，这名警察承认向这名青少年开枪致命，周四因故意杀人罪接受正式调查 - 相当于在盎格鲁-撒克逊司法管辖区受到指控。他被预防性拘留。

;

;他的律师洛朗-弗兰克·利纳德 (Laurent-Franck Lienard) 表示，他的当事人向下瞄准了司机的腿，但被撞到，导致他朝自己的胸部开枪。 “显然（警官）不想杀死司机，”利纳德在 BFM 电视台上说道。

;

;一些西方国家政府周四警告其在法国的公民要小心谨慎。

;

;美国大使馆在推文中表示，美国人“应避免大规模集会和警察活动频繁的地区”，而英国当局则敦促英国人在旅行时监控媒体、避免抗议并查看建议。

;

;过夜在法国南部，警察发射了催泪瓦斯手榴弹，马赛的旅游热点老港因年轻人与警察发生冲突而被疏散。

;

;在法国北部的鲁贝，一场火灾摧毁了 TESSI 公司的办公室和数名员工。汽车被纵火。

;

;这次骚乱让人回想起 2005 年全国范围内持续三周的骚乱，当时的总统雅克·希拉克 (Jacques Chirac) 被迫宣布进入紧急状态。

;

;那波骚乱巴黎郊区克利希苏布瓦爆发暴力事件，两名年轻人因躲避警察而在变电站触电身亡。

; Fri, 30 Jun 2023 19:25:08 +0800 Hollywood faces possible second strike as actors“ talks near deadlinehttps://reuters.com/article/television-actors/hollywood-faces-possible-second-strike-as-actors-talks-near-deadline-idUSKBN2YG0M6

;;6 月 7 日，SAG-AFTRA 和美国作家协会的成员在美国加利福尼亚州洛杉矶派拉蒙影城外的纠察线上行走, 2023 REUTERS/Mike Blake/档案照片;
;

;Netflix Inc ;(NFLX.O);，华特迪士尼公司 ;(DIS.N); 和好莱坞的其他主要电影和电视制片厂正在争分夺秒地在周五午夜的最后期限前与 SAG-AFTRA 演员工会达成协议，避免今年夏天的第二次罢工。

;

;一线明星包括詹妮弗·劳伦斯和梅丽尔·斯特里普，;本周致工会领导层的一封信;表示，如果谈判代表无法就更高的基本工资和人工智能 (AI) 使用的保障措施达成“变革性协议”，他们准备辞职。

;

;这封信是在工会谈判代表发布了一段视频后发出的。表示他们的谈判“非常富有成效”，这可能表明达成协议是指日可待的。

;

;代表 16 万名演员的美国演员工会联合会 (SAG-AFTRA) 举行罢工，将使已经陷入困境的好莱坞电影公司雪上加霜。美国作家协会 (WGA) 停工近两个月。

;

;;11,500 名编剧的罢工;导致大量电视制作停工，并推迟了包括漫威《雷电》和《刀锋》在内的电影的拍摄。如果演员也罢工，任何正在进行的拍摄都必须停止。

;

;SAG-AFTRA 和 WGA 的领导人表示，随着流媒体电视和 ;生成式人工智能等新技术的出现，;他们担心这可能是用于编写剧本或创建数字演员。

;

;一些演员公开表示支持罢工。

;

;新电影《夺宝奇兵》的主演菲比·沃勒-布里奇，指出她作为 WGA 成员已经开始罢工。

;

;“我非常希望美国演员工会 (SAG) 也能效仿并站出来支持编剧，我真的希望我们可以解决这个问题，”沃勒-布里奇在《夺宝奇兵》伦敦首映式上接受路透社采访时说道。

;

;SAG-AFTRA ;已经投票;，如果谈判在周五晚上合同到期之前破裂，其领导人有权要求停工

;

;“我认为我们需要演员们罢工，这样一切才能得到解决，”电影制片人和演员贾德·阿帕托告诉路透社。 “所有这些问题都影响到每个人。”

;

;代表电影公司进行谈判的电影和电视制片人联盟 (AMPTP) 对与 SAG-AFTRA 正在进行的谈判没有发表评论。

;

; >;

;对于编剧，AMPTP 表示已提出“慷慨”的加薪，但无法同意编剧的所有要求。自 5 月 2 日编剧罢工开始以来，制片厂和 WGA 尚未举行过会谈。

;

;WGA 罢工是 ;打击餐饮服务商、道具供应商和其他小企业;，这些企业的大部分收入来自好莱坞制作。上一次作家罢工发生在 2007 年和 2008 年，加州经济损失估计为 21 亿美元。

;支持特朗普的团体被称为路透社对联邦选举委员会的初步财务披露的分析发现，MAGA Inc 今年花费了超过 2300 万美元，几乎全部用于攻击德桑蒂斯的广告。

;Trump's Save America group, which he set up before launching his 2024 campaign, transferred $60 million left over from the 2022 midterms to MAGA Inc, Save America's disclosures show.

;

;Campaign finance experts say the transfers helped each side supercharge early spending while creating significant financial ties between the candidates and outside groups.

;

;Trump's Save America group is a political committee that ;by law; cannot back his own election bids, according to legal experts.

;

;"This just shows the lie that the Super PACs are independent," said Stuart McPhail, a campaign finance lawyer at Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington, a nonpartisan watchdog. "Why would the candidates take tens of millions of dollars they control and give it to a group they don't control? They wouldn't."

;

;Another nonpartisan watchdog group, the Campaign Legal Center, has filed legal challenges with the Federal Election Commission against the MAGA Inc and Never Back Down transfers, arguing the Super PACs' funding was partly controlled by the candidates.

;

;"We've never had anything quite like this before in campaign finance," said Saurav Ghosh, a lawyer at the Campaign Legal Center.

;

;The Trump and DeSantis campaigns did not respond to requests for comment, but both Super PACs said the transfers were legal.

;

;Never Back Down's transfer came from a group that raised the money under the name Friends of Ron DeSantis, but changed its name shortly before sending the funds. Never Back Down officials say DeSantis didn't order the transfer.

;Never Back Down's ads highlight the Florida governor's opposition to abortion and paint DeSantis, 44, as more youthful and composed than Trump, 77.

;Campaign finance experts say that for the groups backing Trump and DeSantis, the transfers send a message that giving to the Super PAC is as good as giving to the campaign.

;;Protesters hold signs as demonstrators for and against the US Supreme Court decision to strike down race-conscious student admissions programs at Harvard University and the University of North Carolina confront each other, in Washington, US, June 29, 2023. REUTERS/Evelyn Hockstein/File photo;
;

;The Supreme Court's decision on Thursday barring race-conscious admissions policies will force universities to find new ways to attract a diverse student body – but experts said such efforts will likely open a new front in what has been a decades-long legal battle over race and college admissions.

;

;The majority opinion, written by Chief Justice John Roberts and joined by the court's five other conservatives, held that giving some minority applicants a boost over others based on their race violated the US Constitution.

;

;But Roberts said admissions officers at colleges could consider "an applicant's discussion of how race affected his or her life, be it through discrimination, inspiration, or otherwise," as long as they do so on an individual basis.

;

;"A benefit to a student who overcame racial discrimination, for example, must be tied to that student's courage and determination," he wrote. "In other words, the student must be treated based on his or her experiences as an individual — not on the basis of race."

;

;That provision could make application essays, in which students often write about formative personal experiences, even more important as colleges strive for racial diversity. But the inherent nuance in taking race into account without allowing it to form the sole basis for an advantage creates a gray area that could lead to new lawsuits, experts said.

;

;"The court made very clear that it will not tolerate workarounds or end-runs," said Dayna Bowen Matthew, the dean of George Washington University's law school. "What we can do, according to the court, is we can look at whether an applicant's race gave them 'courage and determination,' and that courage and determination is part of our university's goals."

;

;But Brian Fitzpatrick, a law professor at Vanderbilt University who opposes affirmative action, said he expected some schools to "try to drive a truck through that little paragraph," leading to "years and years" of litigation.

;

;Edward Blum, the founder of the group that brought Thursday's Supreme Court case, made it clear in a statement that he would be watching schools' reaction closely.

;

;"The law will not tolerate direct proxies for racial classifications," Blum said. "We remain vigilant and intend to initiate litigation should universities defiantly flout this clear ruling."

;

;The court's decision also did not explicitly bar schools from employing race-neutral programs to improve diversity.

;

;In California, where voters banned affirmative action for public universities more than two decades ago, the state has spent more than $500 million on alternative approaches, including the use of socio-economic status, geographic location and targeted recruitment at schools with high numbers of minority students.

;

;But such programs could draw legal challenges claiming that schools are simply using other criteria as a substitute for race.

;

;In Virginia, for instance, a coalition of Asian American parents sued a high school that eliminated the use of standardized tests and guaranteed spots for top students at every area public middle school, a change that resulted in more Black and Latino students and fewer Asian American students.

;

;A divided ;appeals court rejected; the parents' claim, but many legal observers say the Supreme Court could choose to take up the case.

;

;"Some of the same groups that have been challenging race-conscious decision-making have also begun to challenge race-neutral measures that are clearly designed to diversify," said Evan Caminker, a law professor at the University of Michigan. "There may be another shoe that some opponents of affirmative action would like to see dropped."

;

;Some employment lawyers also warned that Thursday's decision, while focused on colleges, nevertheless could encourage more legal challenges to corporate diversity and inclusion programs.

;

;Companies typically do not adopt the kinds of practices used by colleges that the court called out in its decision, such as assigning a "plus" to an applicant solely because of their race.

;

;But in practice, corporate programs can sometimes give the appearance of granting preferences to particular groups, and the Supreme Court ruling could fuel opposition to them, said Krissy Katzenstein, a partner at Baker McKenzie in New York who represents employers.

;

;"This is likely to generate additional challenges to (diversity) efforts, and there is language in the decision that will be seized on," she said.
